entries.content: Answer a question with a question to understand the true intent or scope of the inquiry.
"Do you want me to tell you the truth or do you want me to tell you what I think you want to hear?"
entries.notes: Used to clarify the desired level of honesty/candor when asked a question.

entries.content: When asked 'Where do you see yourself in 5 years?', clarify: 'Do you mean within this organization, just generally as a human being, or something else?'
entries.notes: Example of using a clarifying question to narrow down the scope of an open-ended question.

entries.content: Use questions to get the prospect to articulate the reason or value themselves, uncovering their perspective.
After demonstrating a strength (answering with a question), ask the interviewer: 'What do you think is my number one job in a sales meeting?'
entries.notes: Gets the prospect to state the core objective (like getting to the truth), reinforcing the value of the demonstrated skill.

entries.content: Challenge the premise of a question to get to the root definition or understanding of a concept.
When asked about losing a sale, challenge the term: 'Do you believe you can lose a sale?'
entries.notes: Leads to clarifying that you can't lose what you never had, reframing 'failure' as 'failure to disqualify'.

entries.content: Ask a question designed to uncover the prospect's specific criteria for success and potential future objections upfront.
"If you offer me this job... what will I have done... for you to say hiring Benjamin was the best decision we made last year?"
entries.notes: A question designed to uncover the prospect's definition of success and potential future expectations/objections.

entries.content: "Between now and when I leave this meeting, how can I demonstrate to you today here and now that I'm going to be able to do that?"
entries.notes: Follow-up question to the 'success criteria' question, isolating what needs to be proven *now* to overcome potential future objections.

focus_area: Objection Discovery: Clarifying questions, isolation, root cause
